text:
Not directly a julia question, but:
Are methods like SGD and minibatch optimization useful for fitting traditional analytical models? I only see them mentioned in context of neutral networks.
Maybe someone has experience with this, or pointers...

text: If you are not very deep into the literature i would recommend watching this talk, if you are a person which can learn from video.

text: At least judging from the title I don't see how this talk is relevant - I'm definitely interested in gradient-informed optimization

elements.text: At least judging from the title I don't see how this talk is relevant - I'm definitely interested in gradient-informed optimization

text: Ok. I jut thought whatever she says about getting the gradient also applies mostly for approximating the hessian from the gradient. If you have hessian available too then there is not sense in watching the talk, i agree.

<@UGTUKUHLN> Are you talking about fitting parameters to an analytical model. I think that SGD and minibatch optimization are used. But if you have data of the size that requires batching and all, then that usually suggests a pretty large or complex model. In such cases, estimating things like transition matrices gets difficult if you have a lot of states. There are a couple of good books that I know about. The Gosavi book Simulation-Based Optimization is pretty good. There is a good connection between optimization of these large models and reinforcement learning--as the video indicates. If you want something more model-based, then "Conditional Monte Carlo-Gradient Estimation and Optimization Applications" by Fu may be good.
